overview_metadata.overview_subtitle: Using Inverse Operations to Solve Equations
overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students solve a two-step equation using a double number line and identify which Properties of Equality they applied. The properties provide the connection to use inverse operations to solve two-step equations. Students apply these methods to solve two-step equations.

overview_item_data_items: I can use the Properties of Equality to solve equations and algebraically check the solutions.
Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to represent constraints or relationships between the quantities.
Solve word problems leading to equations of the form <math><mi>p</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>r</mi></math> and <math><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy=

>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>r</mi></math>, where <math><mi>p</mi></math>, <math><mi>q</mi></math>, and <math><mi>r</mi></math> are specific rational numbers. Solve equations fluently. Compare an algebraic solution to an arithmetic solution, identifying the sequence of the operations used in each approach. For example, the perimeter of a rectangle is 54 cm. Its length is 6 cm. What is its width?
There are two specific structures of two-step equations, <math><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi></math> and <math><mi>a</mi><mo stretchy=
>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi></math>. You can solve these equations by applying the Properties of Equality.
When you apply the Properties of Equality to an equation, the equivalent equation has the same solution as the original equation.
When solving two-step equations, you can apply the Properties of Equality in any order.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students write an equation to represent a situation and discuss strategies to solve it.
Students analyze strategies for using inverse operations to solve two-step equations.
Students write two-step equations to model real-world situations.
Students generalize the solution strategy to solve a two-step equation.
